item.title: New R Markdown Example - First Python
item.description:
Nulla ornare odio vitae malesuada imperdiet. Sed ac nulla ipsum. Suspendisse pharetra massa id hendrerit blandit. Nam tempus enim sed nulla varius, in volutpat risus bibendum. Aenean non sagittis arcu. Donec ultricies gravida rhoncus. Fusce sed mattis sapien. Donec at feugiat augue, sit amet consequat erat. Nulla ornare odio vitae malesuada imperdiet. Sed ac nulla ipsum. Suspendisse pharetra massa id hendrerit blandit. Nam tempus enim sed nulla varius, in volutpat risus bibendum. Aenean non sagittis arcu. Donec ultricies gravida rhoncus. Fusce sed mattis sapien. Donec at feugiat augue, sit amet consequat erat.

Here is an example of a little math

\[\LARGE{x = \frac{-b \pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}}\]

Leaflet Demo

#{r}
library(leaflet)

m <- leaflet() %>%
  addTiles() %>%  # Add default OpenStreetMap map tiles
  addMarkers(lng=174.768, lat=-36.852, popup="The birthplace of R")
m  # Print the map

Dygraph Demo

#{r}
library(dygraphs)
dygraph(nhtemp, main = "New Haven Temperatures") %>% 
  dyRangeSelector(dateWindow = c("1920-01-01", "1960-01-01"))

R Bokeh

#{r}
library(rbokeh)
figure() %>%
  ly_points(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, data = iris,
    color = Species, glyph = Species,
    hover = list(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width))

Highcharter … needs jQuery … work this

VisNetwork

#{r}
library(visNetwork)
nodes <- data.frame(id = 1:6, title = paste("node", 1:6), 
                    shape = c("dot", "square"),
                    size = 10:15, color = c("blue", "red"))
edges <- data.frame(from = 1:5, to = c(5, 4, 6, 3, 3))
visNetwork(nodes, edges) %>%
  visOptions(highlightNearest = TRUE, nodesIdSelection = TRUE)

networkD3 Demo

#{r}
library(networkD3)
data(MisLinks, MisNodes)
forceNetwork(Links = MisLinks, Nodes = MisNodes, Source = "source",
             Target = "target", Value = "value", NodeID = "name",
             Group = "group", opacity = 0.4)

DT Demo jQuery Maybe ???

RGL Demo

#{r}
library(rgl)
library(rglwidget)
library(htmltools)

theta <- seq(0, 6*pi, len=100)
xyz <- cbind(sin(theta), cos(theta), theta)
lineid <- plot3d(xyz, type="l", alpha = 1:0, 
                 lwd = 5, col = "blue")["data"]

browsable(tagList(
  rglwidget(elementId = "example", width = 500, height = 400,
            controllers = "player"),
  playwidget("example", 
             ageControl(births = theta, ages = c(0, 0, 1),
                        objids = lineid, alpha = c(0, 1, 0)),
                        start = 1, stop = 6*pi, step = 0.1, 
                        rate = 6,elementId = "player")
))

DiagrammeR Demo

#{r}
library(DiagrammeR)
grViz("
  digraph {
    layout = twopi
    node [shape = circle]
    A -> {B C D} 
  }")

Metricsgraphics Demo … Not working

#{python}
print('hello, world')

Here is an example using plotly, as expressed by the following code segment

#{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(plotly)

fig <- plot_ly(data = iris, x = ~Sepal.Length, y = ~Petal.Length)

fig

Here is an even fancier example

#{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(plotly)

count <- 3000

x <- c()
y <- c()
z <- c()
c <- c()

for (i in 1:count) {
  r <- i * (count - i)
  x <- c(x, r * cos(i / 30))
  y <- c(y, r * sin(i / 30))
  z <- c(z, i)
  c <- c(c, i)
}

data <- data.frame(x, y, z, c)

fig <- plot_ly(data, x = ~x, y = ~y, z = ~z, type = 'scatter3d', mode = 'lines',
        line = list(width = 4, color = ~c, colorscale = list(c(0,'#BA52ED'), c(1,'#FCB040'))))

fig
#{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(threejs)
z <- seq(-10, 10, 0.05)
x <- cos(z)
y <- sin(z)
scatterplot3js(x,y,z, color=rainbow(length(z)))

item.title: New R Plots Demo Python
item.description:
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nulla elementum suscipit lorem at pretium. Nullam porta, felis ut vulputate vestibulum, diam sapien tincidunt ipsum, a volutpat augue enim ut mi. Pellentesque fermentum quam felis, quis pharetra risus euismod a. Nam sagittis ipsum id porttitor finibus. Phasellus feugiat felis at tincidunt blandit. Pellentesque nisi ipsum, malesuada non felis a, scelerisque consectetur ipsum. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Donec nec gravida nunc. In vulputate pellentesque enim, vitae suscipit mi dignissim ut. Vestibulum tristique leo et lectus sodales, a ultricies ipsum accumsan. Cras vehicula pulvinar urna tincidunt dignissim. Etiam velit tellus, malesuada bibendum varius et, vulputate eu purus. Suspendisse felis libero, molestie laoreet vulputate non, lobortis sed libero. Praesent at ipsum vulputate, vestibulum erat vel, molestie nibh. Sed ut erat eget augue dictum imperdiet eget bibendum sapien.

\[\LARGE{y=mx+b}\]

# library
library(ggplot2)
 
# Iris dataset is natively provided by R
#head(iris)
 
# use options!
ggplot(iris, aes(x=Sepal.Length, y=Sepal.Width)) + 
    geom_point(
        color="orange",
        fill="#69b3a2",
        shape=21,
        alpha=0.5,
        size=6,
        stroke = 2
        )
